description: Hypovolemic shock is a condition that occurs when the body doesnt have enough blood to function properly. This can be caused by severe bleeding, diarrhea, vomiting, or burns. The symptoms of hypovolemic shock include rapid breathing, weak pulse, dizziness, confusion, and low blood pressure.
treatment: The treatment for hypovolemic shock is to replace the lost fluids. This may be done with intravenous fluids or blood transfusions.

description: Sepsis is a serious infection that can lead to organ failure and death. It occurs when the bodys response to infection injures its own tissues and organs. The symptoms of sepsis include fever, chills, rapid breathing, fast heart rate, confusion, and low blood pressure.
treatment: The treatment for sepsis is antibiotics and fluids. In severe cases, patients may need to be admitted to the hospital for intensive care.

description: Appendicitis is an inflammation of the appendix, a small, finger-shaped pouch that projects from the large intestine. The symptoms of appendicitis include abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. The pain typically starts in the lower right abdomen, but it can also spread to other parts of the body.
treatment: The treatment for appendicitis is surgery to remove the appendix. This is usually done as an emergency surgery.

description: Food poisoning is an illness caused by eating contaminated food. The symptoms of food poisoning include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. The severity of the symptoms depends on the type of bacteria or virus that caused the contamination.
treatment: The treatment for food poisoning is rest and fluids. In severe cases, patients may need to be hospitalized.

description: Gastroenteritis is an inflammation of the stomach and intestines. It can be caused by a virus, bacteria, or parasite. The symptoms of gastroenteritis include diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and fever.
treatment: The treatment for gastroenteritis is rest and fluids. In severe cases, patients may need to be hospitalized.

description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the meninges, the membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord. It can be caused by a virus, bacteria, or fungus. The symptoms of meningitis include fever, headache, stiff neck, rash, and sensitivity to light.
treatment: The treatment for meningitis is antibiotics. In severe cases, patients may need to be hospitalized.

description: Encephalitis is an inflammation of the brain. It can be caused by a virus, bacteria, or fungus. The symptoms of encephalitis include fever, headache, stiff neck, confusion, seizures, and coma.

treatment: The treatment for encephalitis depends on the cause. Viral encephalitis is usually treated with antiviral medications. Bacterial encephalitis is treated with antibiotics. Fungal encephalitis is treated with antifungal medications.

description: Guillain-Barré syndrome is a disorder in which the bodys immune system attacks its own nerves. This can lead to muscle weakness, numbness, and paralysis. The symptoms of Guillain-Barré syndrome typically begin with weakness in the legs or arms and gradually spread to other parts of the body.

treatment: The treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome is plasma exchange or intravenous immunoglobulin therapy. These treatments help to remove the antibodies from the body that are attacking the nerves.

description: Anaphylaxis is a severe allergic reaction that can be life-threatening. It is caused by the bodys release of chemicals that cause the airways to narrow, the blood vessels to leak, and the heart to race. The symptoms of anaphylaxis include difficulty breathing, swelling of the face and throat, hives, itching, and nausea and vomiting.

treatment: The treatment for anaphylaxis is an injection of epinephrine. Epinephrine is a hormone that helps to open the airways, constrict the blood vessels, and slow the heart rate. People who are at risk of anaphylaxis should carry an epinephrine auto-injector with them at all times.

description: Toxic shock syndrome is a rare but serious bacterial infection that can cause shock, multiple organ failure, and death. It is most often caused by the bacteria Staphylococcus aureus. The symptoms of toxic shock syndrome include fever, headache, muscle aches, rash, vomiting, diarrhea, and vaginal discharge in women.
treatment: The treatment for toxic shock syndrome is antibiotics and fluids. In severe cases, patients may need to be admitted to the hospital for intensive care.
